lines.speaker: notice
lines.text: You have arrived in the Tasman Sea. Karen joins your conversation.

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Why, hello there! I'm Karen, the dolphin GIF!

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: I was originally created sometime between 2004 and 2009 for [pinkrainbowuk's GeoCities site](https://web.archive.org/web/20091022120101/http://geocities.com/pinkrainbowuk/Index1.html), and I've been trapped here ever since...

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Anyhow, welcome to the global network of deep sea fibre optic cables!

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: If you've made it this far, then you're likely looking for safe passage across the Tasman Sea, am I right?

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: ...yeah!

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: He doesn't say much, does he.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: nope, just a packet with a simple message

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: and that message is "hello," as I'm sure you've seen.

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Well, you're just as valuable as a multi-terabyte file transfer to me, little guy.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: so, wait... the Tasman Sea... is my head going to Australia?

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Sure is. We're taking the Tasman Global Access Cable right on over to Sydney.

settings.text: check out the Tasman Global Access Cable!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: I wonder why we didn't get sent straight to the US?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: it's like the guide said, the orb in the router probably sent us through to Australia first because of traffic flow.

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Ha ha, that Orb! Such a prankster.

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Anyway, you folks done chatting?

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Hop on my back and we'll go on an adventure!!

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: I hope you're ready for things to get weird!!

lines.speaker: TV
lines.text: uhhhh uhhhhhh...

lines.speaker: TV
lines.text: uhhhh... a head... uhhhh... a face.... hmm...

lines.speaker: TV
lines.text: ...a face... a face... something... I haven't seen in a long time...

lines.speaker: TV
lines.text: ...dropped... I was dropped... dumped... planted... like a seed... from a great ship...

lines.speaker: TV
lines.text: returned... to the ground... into the deep... from where I come...

lines.speaker: TV
lines.text: my origins... span the globe... I was once rock... mountain... earth... cut out... from my homes... carried... to the factory floor... dunked... married with chemical... rarified... rendered... manufactured...

lines.speaker: TV
lines.text: becoming... vapor. becoming... gas. becoming... liquid. becoming... solid. becoming... glass. becoming... becoming... becoming...

lines.speaker: TV
lines.text: my... my flesh... built... built to show... shine... my cathrode ray tube... blasting photons into the mind's eye... red... green... blue...

lines.speaker: TV
lines.text: distributed... sold... bought... watched... used... broken... waiting... waiting... waiting... stasis...

lines.speaker: TV
lines.text: corroded... collapsing... back into the everywhere... and the everywhen... I am shoveled into the ship... to discard... into the sacrifice zone...

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: uh... hm... that was intense!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: yeah, that was a lot.

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Such is the fate of all electronics when they are no longer useful to humans.

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: That TV is yesterday's technology, but eventually all the tech of today's internet––the computers, routers, smart phones, even the solar panels that harvest energy––will break and become part of the 50+ million metric tons of e-waste that the human race produces each year.

lines.speaker: ITG
lines.text: *beeping*

lines.speaker: ITG
lines.text: Since the advent of Internet-of-Things technology, where devices have increasingly become expected to connect to the internet (our phones, watches, refrigerators) the internet is increasingly made up of a bunch of random future-junk.

lines.speaker: ITG
lines.text: And that junk is extremely toxic. E-waste is the world's fastest growing and largest stream of toxic waste. Most of our technology has things like arsenic, lead, chlorine, plastics and heavy metals which contaminate the air, soil and water when manufactured and disposed of.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: wow, well that's definitely a cost...

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: wait, can we back up for a second? At this point I expect this kind of information from the internet travel guide, but why do you know so much about this, Karen?

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Oh, I eat garbage.

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Actually that reminds me, all this swimming is making me hungry, do you think you guys could keep an eye out for some food when you get to Australia?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: ...sure, Karen.
